repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Financial Sector and Business
            Environment Credit, Private Sector Development Adjustment
            Credit, and,  Financial and Private Sector Institutional
            Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit gives mixed results in rating
            the three operations, concurring, or not with the
            Implementation Completion (ICR) reports' ratings, as
            follows. It downgrades the Financial Sector and Business
            Environment (FSBEP) Project outcome to unsatisfactory, its
            sustainability to unlikely, institutional development
            impacts to negligible, including both Bank and Borrower
            performances to unsatisfactory; similarly, the Private
            Sector Development Adjustment Credit (PSDAC) is downgraded
            to moderately satisfactory outcomes, unlikely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impacts,
            satisfactory Bank performance, although concurs with a
            satisfactory Borrower performance; and, ratings on the
            Financial and Private Sector Institutional Development
            (FPSIDP) are also downgraded to unsatisfactory project
            outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts, yet, concurs with
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower. Some of
            the main lessons from these projects suggest that: The
            ethnic divide, distrust, and governance problems, are the
            key constraints to improving the environment for private
            sector development (PSD), and fostering sustainable growth
            in Guyana. At the project level, all future Bank operations,
            including their components and processes (e.g. consultations
            on project design, hiring of consultants, procurement,
            selection of trainees, choice of regulatory options, etc.),
            should address the way to at least, avoid deepening
            distrust, and if possible, serve to build trust across the
            racial divide. Transparency should be the key watchword for
            both the Government, and donors. In addition, more
            diagnostic work on incentives, institutions, and social
            capital is needed, with a view to identifying strategies,
            and tactics for rationalizing incentives, building
            sustainable institutions, and fostering social capital.
            Understanding the political economy is essential to project
            choice, and design.

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Financial and Private Sector
            Institutional Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            are substantial. Lessons suggest the following. The Bank
            should consider including in its legal covenants, provisions
            which would avoid delaying project components if the
            government chooses to substitute certain project activities
            with grant funds, which had not yet been approved, nor
            received. Therefore, the lack of grant money will not be a
            factor delaying the execution of important project
            components. In a small developing country striving to emerge
            from poverty, with very limited capacity, it is unrealistic
            to expect transformation of the financial sector into
            institutional framework models that enable private sector
            investment, all in a relatively short timeframe; rather, a
            longer time-frame should be expected. Further lessons
            address the need to design privatization programs in a
            socially sensitive manner, e.g., by including in enterprise
            sale contracts, clauses to protect workers and minority
            investors; a technical assistance operation can be effective
            and quickly disbursed if a previous lending operation, or
            set of actions had already laid the ground for its prompt
            implementation; and, project ownership and commitment is
            critical to project success, in this case the task team
            worked to ensure a consistent level of involvement of the
            Government in project supervision, and monitoring.

TF036582-LAC REGION - FINANCIAL SECTOR,

5084664.majtheme: Rule of law,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Financial and Private Sector
            Institutional Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial and Private Sector
            Institutional Development Project, will support
            institutional reforms, and, improve regulatory frameworks on
            the overall financial sector, thus, supporting private
            sector development, and, enhancing banking, insurance, and
            financial operations. The three main components are: 1)
            financial sector development, where expertise, and
            technology upgrade will be developed, for processing banking
            liquidity/solvency problems through technical assistance;
            regulatory frameworks will be updated, covering financial
            institutions as a whole; and, the financial conditions of
            state-owned banks, will be restructured, to include an
            assessment on privatization options; 2) private sector
            development, to transfer state enterprises to the private
            sector. The component will provide funds for technical
            assistance, training, and equipment, in support of the
            privatization process. Additionally, a framework for
            facilitating public offering of shares, of those privatized
            enterprises, will be developed, and, socially equitable
            policies, will ensure sound safeguards' protection; 3)
            development of public business services, to establish a
            national contractors registry. Funding will be provided to
            revise, and develop public procurement procedures, and
            guidelines, and, update the external auditing capacity of
            the public sector.
